p.s: Sonnet 60 is a poem written by the English poet and playwright William Shakespeare.
Like many of Shakespeare's sonnets, Sonnet 60 is a love poem.
It is also traditionally believed to have been written for a young man.
This sonnet is not only about love, but also about the transience of time and beauty.
The lyrical I realizes how everything comes to an end and nothing stays forever.
The Shakespearean sonnet is composed of 14 lines divided into three quatrains four line stanza and a final concluding couplet, rhyming abab cdcd efef gg.
This sonnet rhyme scheme is known as the English sonnet.
Traditionally Shakespearean sonnets are in iambic parameter.
A line of iambic pentameter has give iambic feet a soft syllable followed by a stronger syllable.
Sonnet 60 starts with a metaphor on the sea.
Shakespeare compares the waves reaching the sea with the time that leads to an end.
There is a volta in the first two lines, since he first describes the shore and then he shifts to the fact, that time passes.
The verb hasten (l. 2) he uses is very remarkable because it underlines how the minutes spped up and how they pass faster.
And every place he's been to before reminds him of the transience.
In the second quatrain you can read the poet writtingwriting about religion, christianity.
Describing how even Jesus, who was praised since he was a little child did not love an endless life or was immortal.
The way Jesus crawls to maturity (l. 6) expresses, that he was mature even when he was still crawling as an infant or baby.
People crowned and prasied him for being special, but still his gift could not save him from defeats or his own death.
The crown mentioned in line 6 symbolizes the powerful people to that time who are also slaves of time.
The third and last quatrain is about how time affects beatuy.
Shakespeare thinks that tie takes away or breaks thrugh the flowering time every human has in his youth.
So he thinks the transience of time affects the beauty's brow (l. 10).
These two words have an alliteration to show, that they are connected to each other.
Beauty needs time to express itself and the most beautiful time in life is in the youth.
A beautiful way to explain that everything comes to an end is And nothing stands but for his scythe to mow.
It shows that nothing will stay the way it is, since it'll get scythe down like at a pasture.
A lawn mower is mowing the meadow just like time our life.
An anapher in line 12 and 13 connects the lasst quatrains with the couplet in content.
Shakespeare is menioning that he acknowledges that his time will end, too but even though everything ends he says in hope my verse shall stand.
Which means that he wants his words to reach many people even after his death.
here you have the turning point of the poem.
However this verse shows that Shakespeare accepted the fact that he will be gone one day, but he doesn't want to be forgotten, because his art praises beauty in many ways despite his cruel hand.
He uses a metaphor wth a pronoun his, which stands for the society that doesn't appreciate every kind of beauty.
In conclusion Shakespeare realizes how everything has its own death even holy persons like Jesus.
When mentioning his own end he adds, that he wants his words to stay alive and to protect the beatuy and worth of art from society.
This poem is amazingly composed, it shows the poetspoet's fears and wisdom in a metaphorical way, without being too complicated.
